verses.text: The word of the LORD came to me, saying:
verses.comment: Ezekiel often begins new messages with this phrase, emphasizing direct revelation from God.

verses.text: Son of man, there were two women, daughters of one mother.
verses.comment: The two women represent Samaria and Jerusalem, symbolizing the divided kingdoms of Israel and Judah.

verses.text: They acted like prostitutes in Egypt; they engaged in prostitution from their youth. There, their breasts were fondled and their virgin bosoms caressed.
verses.comment: Prostitution here is used as a metaphor for idolatry and unfaithfulness to God.

verses.text: The older was named Oholah, and her sister was Oholibah. They became mine and gave birth to sons and daughters. Oholah is Samaria, and Oholibah is Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The naming is symbolic: 'Oholah' means 'her own tent' (Samaria: her own worship), and 'Oholibah' means 'my tent is in her' (Jerusalem: true place of God's presence).

verses.text: Oholah played the harlot while she was mine. She lusted after her lovers, the Assyrians, warriors dressed in blue,
verses.comment: Samaria’s alliances with Assyria is likened to infidelity. The color blue was associated with nobility and military power.

verses.text: noblemen and officers, all of them desirable young men, horsemen riding on horses.
verses.comment: Describes the allure of Assyrian power. Israel’s leaders sought worldly strength instead of relying on the LORD.

verses.text: She gave herself as a prostitute to all the elite of the Assyrians, and defiled herself with all the idols of everyone she lusted after.
verses.comment: Idolatry is emphasized as spiritual adultery, a central prophetic theme (cf. Hosea).

verses.text: She did not give up her prostitution she began in Egypt, for in her youth men slept with her, caressed her virgin bosom, and poured out their lust upon her.
verses.comment: Israel’s idolatry began in Egypt, hinting at a pattern of infidelity that predates even their possession of the land.

verses.text: Therefore, I handed her over to her lovers, the Assyrians, after whom she lusted.
verses.comment: Judgment is portrayed as God allowing the consequences of idolatry to come upon his people. Assyria eventually conquers Samaria.

verses.text: They uncovered her nakedness, took her sons and daughters, and killed her with the sword. She became a byword among women, because judgment was executed on her.
verses.comment: Her public shame is symbolic of national disgrace. The idea of nakedness refers to exposure and punishment.

verses.text: Her sister Oholibah saw this, yet she was more corrupt in her lust and in her prostitution, which was worse than that of her sister.
verses.comment: Judah, represented by Jerusalem (Oholibah), is said to go beyond Samaria’s corruption, an intensification of the nation’s sin.

verses.text: She lusted after the Assyrians, governors and officers nearby, those clothed in splendid garments, horsemen riding on horses—all of them desirable young men.
verses.comment: Jerusalem repeats the same sins, seeking power and protection from pagan nations rather than from God.

verses.text: I saw that she too had defiled herself; they both took the same path.
verses.comment: The repetition of sin by both Israel and Judah shows shared guilt and the persistent nature of spiritual infidelity.

verses.text: But she carried her prostitution even further. She saw men portrayed on the wall, images of the Chaldeans, drawn in bright red,
verses.comment: There is an escalation of idolatry; Jerusalem now seeks after Babylonian influence, moving further away from true worship.

verses.text: with belts around their waists, flowing turbans on their heads—all of them having the appearance of officers, like the Babylonians in Chaldea, the land of their birth.
verses.comment: Vivid imagery emphasizes the attraction to foreign ways and power.

verses.text: As soon as she saw them, she lusted after them and sent messengers to them in Chaldea.
verses.comment: Jerusalem actively sought immoral political alliances, further compromising her spiritual integrity.

verses.text: Then the Babylonians came to her, to her bedroom of love, and defiled her with their lust. After she was defiled by them, she turned away from them in disgust.
verses.comment: Sin is portrayed as ultimately bringing shame and disappointment; alliances with other nations are spiritually destructive.

verses.text: When she revealed her prostitution and uncovered her nakedness, I turned away from her in disgust, just as I had turned away from her sister.
verses.comment: God’s turning away is a metaphor for judgment—distance from God's protective presence.

verses.text: Yet she increased her prostitution, recalling the days of her youth, when she was a prostitute in the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: Spiritual unfaithfulness deepens with repeated patterns from the past.

verses.text: She lusted after lovers with genitals like those of donkeys and emissions like those of stallions.
verses.comment: The explicit imagery amplifies the gravity of Israel's idolatry, showing degradation and spiritual uncleanness.

verses.text: So you revisited the lewdness of your youth, when in Egypt your bosom was caressed and your youthful breasts fondled.
verses.comment: Jerusalem’s sin is deliberately compared to former Egypt bondage, reinforcing the cyclical nature of their unfaithfulness.

verses.text: Therefore, Oholibah, the LORD says this: I will stir up your lovers against you, those you turned away from, and I will bring them against you from every side:
verses.comment: God uses the very nations with whom Jerusalem sinned as instruments of judgment—a recurring biblical theme.

verses.text: the Babylonians and all the Chaldeans, Pekod, Shoa, and Koa, and all the Assyrians with them, desirable young men, governors and rulers, officers and men of renown, all riding on horses.
verses.comment: Historical references to the ever-expanding power of Babylon and Assyria, who would conquer Jerusalem.

verses.text: They will come against you with weapons, chariots, and wagons, and with a crowd of people. They will assault you from every side with small shields, large shields, and helmets. I will commit the judgment to them, and they shall judge you according to their customs.
verses.comment: Foreigners would carry out judgment in a way alien and harsh compared to Israel’s own law.

verses.text: I will set my jealousy against you, and they shall deal with you in fury. They will cut off your nose and ears, and those of you who remain will fall by the sword. They will take your sons and daughters, and those left will be consumed by fire.
verses.comment: Divine jealousy represents God’s love for his people and intolerance of spiritual betrayal. Physical mutilation was a punishment for adultery among pagan nations.

verses.text: They shall also strip you of your clothes and take away your beautiful jewelry.
verses.comment: Shame and loss of blessing are common symbols for the consequences of sin.

verses.text: I will put an end to your lewdness and the prostitution you began in Egypt. You will not look with longing on them or remember Egypt anymore.
verses.comment: God’s discipline is meant to break the cycle of idolatry and restore spiritual faithfulness.

verses.text: For this is what the Lord GOD says: I am about to deliver you into the hands of those you hate, into the hands of those from whom you turned away in disgust.
verses.comment: God acts justly, at times allowing people’s own choices to result in their judgment.

verses.text: They will treat you with hatred, take away all you have worked for, and leave you naked and bare. The shame of your prostitution will be exposed, your lewdness and promiscuity.
verses.comment: God exposes sin to bring repentance, which leads ultimately to restoration.

verses.text: These things will happen to you because you have played the prostitute with the nations and defiled yourself with their idols.
verses.comment: The heart of the matter is always spiritual unfaithfulness, not merely political alliances.

verses.text: You have followed the path of your sister; therefore I will put her cup into your hand.
verses.comment: The 'cup' symbolizes divine wrath (see also Rev. 14:10).

verses.text: This is what the Lord GOD says: 'You will drink your sister's cup, deep and wide— you will be laughed at and held in derision, for it holds much.'
verses.comment: The 'cup' represents overwhelming judgment and disgrace. The shared fate of both kingdoms points to the need for unity in true faith.

verses.text: You will be filled with drunkenness and sorrow, a cup of horror and desolation, the cup of your sister Samaria.
verses.comment: The metaphor connects with the theme of spiritual sobriety and the consequences of sin (cf. 1 Pet. 5:8).

verses.text: You shall drink it and drain it out; you shall gnaw its shards and tear your breasts. For I have spoken, declares the Lord GOD.
verses.comment: The completeness of judgment is symbolized by drinking the cup to the dregs.

verses.text: Therefore this is what the Lord GOD says: Because you have forgotten me and cast me behind your back, you will bear the consequences of your lewdness and immorality.
verses.comment: Forgetting God always leads to spiritual ruin. This points forward to the need for a spiritual restoration through repentance.

verses.text: The LORD said to me: Son of man, will you judge Oholah and Oholibah? Then declare to them their abominations.
verses.comment: Prophets are tasked not only with warning, but with calling Israel to repentance—anticipating the ministry of Christ and his Church.

verses.text: For they have committed adultery, and blood is on their hands. With their idols they have committed adultery, and even offered up their sons, born to me, as food for them.
verses.comment: Child sacrifice was practiced among the Canaanites. This shows the depth of unfaithfulness that must be repented of for true restoration.

verses.text: Moreover, this they have done to me: they have defiled my sanctuary on the same day and profaned my Sabbaths.
verses.comment: Violating worship and the Lord’s day demonstrates a breakdown in all aspects of covenant faithfulness—a warning not to neglect true worship and the sacraments.

verses.text: On the very day they sacrificed their children to their idols, they entered my sanctuary and profaned it. That is what they did in my house.
verses.comment: The mingling of idolatry and worship—a syncretism—shows the necessity for purity in communal worship.

verses.text: Furthermore, they sent for men to come from a distance, to whom a messenger was sent; and, look, when they came, you bathed, painted your eyes, and adorned yourself with ornaments.
verses.comment: Adornment is used here as a metaphor for seduction towards idolatry and worldly alliances instead of faithfulness to God.

verses.text: You sat on an elaborate couch, with a table spread before it, on which you put my incense and my oil.
verses.comment: Elements meant for worship are wrongly used in the pursuit of other gods—true worship should always be kept pure and holy.

verses.text: The sound of a carefree crowd was around her, and with men of the common sort were drunkards brought from the wilderness. They put bracelets on the arms of the women and beautiful crowns on their heads.
verses.comment: The scene resembles a pagan celebration. The bestowal of crowns and bracelets hints at a counterfeit honor, contrasting the true crown of life promised by God.

verses.text: Then I said concerning her who was worn out by adultery, 'Will they now continue to commit sexual acts with her, and she with them?'
verses.comment: The image is one of exhaustion and devaluation—sin does not satisfy, but leaves one empty.

verses.text: Yet they went in to her as men go in to a prostitute. So they went in to Oholah and Oholibah, the lewd women.
verses.comment: Repetition of unfaithfulness. The prophets use this metaphor to emphasize the gravity of spiritual idolatry.

verses.text: But righteous men will judge them with the judgment of adulteresses and the judgment of women who shed blood, because they are adulteresses, and blood is on their hands.
verses.comment: God’s justice is impartial; the language of blood guilt reinforces the seriousness of the covenant.

verses.text: For this is what the Lord GOD says: Bring an assembly against them and give them over to terror and plunder.
verses.comment: Judgment is thorough and communal. The assembly may foreshadow a future gathering for judgment (cf. Matt 25:31-33).

verses.text: The assembly will stone them and cut them down with their swords. They will kill their sons and daughters and burn their houses with fire.
verses.comment: The execution of judgment mimics the law for adulterers. The severity highlights the seriousness of covenant violations.

verses.text: So I will put an end to lewdness in the land, that all women may take a warning and not imitate your lewdness.
verses.comment: Judgment has a moral and didactic purpose; God's goal is restoration of holiness and right worship.

verses.text: You will suffer the penalty for your lewdness and bear the consequences of your sins of idolatry. Then you will know that I am the Lord GOD.
verses.comment: Judgment, though severe, ultimately reminds Israel of the LORD’s sovereignty—pointing towards an eventual spiritual renewal and new covenant in Christ.
